results.title: Not one less = Yi ge dou bu neng shao
results.creator_credit: Beijing New Picture Film Company, Guangxi Film Studio, Zhao Yu and Zhang Yimou
results.brief_description: Directed by Yimou Zhang, the rural drama “Not one less” is a study in poverty and the determination of one teenage girl. Wei Minzhi is a barely educated thirteen-year-old, who takes on a job teaching young children at an impoverished village school. As the regular teacher leaves he promises Wei bonus pay if, upon his return, all the students are still in school. Inexperienced and overwhelmed, but relentlessly stubborn, Wei faces ingratitude and her own misery as she grapples with the recalcitrant students. When one boy is sent to work in the city, where he lives on the street, Wei pursues him. Once there Wei is overwhelmed by the crowds, bustling street life and enormity of the task of finding a young boy amid the vast city and innumerable homeless children who reside there. Here Zhang steers away from the lush melodramas, such as “Raise the red lantern”, “Red sorghum” and “Shanghai Triad”, in favour of a sparse aesthetic that speaks of the plight of rural Chinese, portraying village life decimated by the commercialisation of China.

results.title: Not my problem
results.creator_credit: Barr Films, Dan Bessie and Ann Vracin
results.brief_description: Dave is the usual gregarious 16 year-old. Baseball, homework and Susan, his current love, take most of his time. But when Susan suspects she is pregnant, Dave won’t alter his schedule to discuss the problem. As he tells his friends, “If she does get herself pregnant, it’s not my problem.” Only Jim, one of Dave’s friends, tries to convince him that it is his problem…and his and Susan’s. When Susan comes to the baseball field to talk with Dave, the reality of the situation suddenly becomes clear. They have some very important decisions to make…together.

results.title: Not just a spectator
results.creator_credit: Town and Country Productions and Bill Latto
results.brief_description: It is a mistake to think that physically disabled people cannot play sport. They can actively compete in many sports and recreational activities, and greatly benefit from the special classes geared to their needs. Shows how the trained instructors, helpers and general public can help and encourage them.

results.title: Not fourteen again
results.creator_credit: Big Picture Company, Spirited Films, Jenny Day and Gillian Armstrong
results.brief_description: Not fourteen again is the fourth in a series of film documentaries about the social histories of three working class women. The series examines the womens’ achievements, failures and changing attitudes. In this episode the women are mothers and wives in their thirties. Their teenage daughters, who are now at the age their mothers were when the series began are documented with equal importance. “Not fourteen again” presents a personal account of three young women and Armstrong, who is by now an old friend, builds a fascinating document.

results.title: Not enough
results.creator_credit: Ben Haanstra Film Productions, Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development and Wim Van Der Velde
results.brief_description: About responsibility to developing countries. The apathy in rich countries is contrasted with the misery and toil of people in poor countries such as India who are attempting to develop their natural resources. Population growth is seen to be greater than increases in food production.

results.title: Not by jeans alone
results.creator_credit: WGBH Educational Foundation, KTEH-TV (Television station : San Jose, Calif.) and Louise Henry
results.brief_description: Notes the market research into consumer behaviour that is carried out by the Levi company prior to the launching of a special range of tailored clothes for men. Shows the breakdown of the market into five distinct groups which have different reasons for purchasing clothes - eg status, work, and comfort; how the target group for the new range of clothes is determined; and how consumer discussion groups with members of this target group elicit their responses to the proposed range. Suitable for upper secondary and tertiary levels.
